title: 108_hr5403
content: The Act titled "Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004" aims to improve the quality of long term care in skilled nursing facilities under Medicare. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to report detailed nursing expenditures, including wages and benefits for nursing staff by staff level. Skilled nursing facilities must report nursing staff wages and benefits separately by staff level for reporting periods starting four months after enactment. The Secretary will redesign reports to meet this requirement. The Secretary will redesign reports with private sector accountants for nursing facility home cost reports. Quality measures appropriate for payment system use will be identified and developed by the Secretary. The Secretary will develop quality measures in consultation with experts for use in the payment system. The Secretary will develop quality measures in consultation with experts, including process, structural, and outcome measures for the payment system. The Secretary will develop quality measures for the payment system, including process, structural, and outcome measures that are valid, reliable, and structured to minimize provider burden and increase accuracy. The payment system quality measures must be valid, reliable, and structured to minimize provider burden and increase accuracy. It should include a quality measure for nursing home staffing and make special provisions for small skilled nursing facilities. The new quality performance measures for the payment system must include a quality measure addressing nursing home staffing levels and make special provisions for small skilled nursing facilities. The Secretary will post a description of these measures on the Medicare program website when they are implemented. The Secretary will post new quality performance measures on the Medicare program website when implemented, including a measure for nursing home staffing levels and provisions for small facilities. The payment rates under subsection (e) shall not be less than the RUG rates effective as of October 1, 2004, with adjustments annually. Payment adjustment methods will be developed. The payment rates under subsection (e) shall not be less than the RUG rates effective as of October 1, 2004, with adjustments annually. The Secretary will develop methods for linking payment rates to quality in consultation with relevant organizations. The Secretary will develop and test methods for linking payment rates to quality in consultation with relevant organizations, making a portion of a provider's payment dependent on performance indicators of quality. The Secretary will develop and test methods for linking payment rates to quality, making a portion of a provider's payment dependent on performance indicators of quality, including special payments for facilities that enhance quality by providing more direct care staffing. The Secretary will test methods for linking payment rates to quality, including special payments for facilities with more direct care staffing. Testing will be done through pilot studies, demonstration projects, and other appropriate methods. The development and testing of quality measures and new payment methods for skilled nursing facilities must be completed within 54 months of the enactment of this subsection, following recommendations by the Institute of Medicine. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the adequacy of Medicaid financing for quality nursing facility care, including an analysis of current and future financing options. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on financing options for quality nursing facility care, including Medicaid adequacy, Medicare cross-subsidization, industry margins, trends impact, and demographic changes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on financing options for quality nursing facility care, including Medicaid adequacy, Medicare cross-subsidization, industry margins, trends impact, and demographic changes. The study will also explore options for addressing payment issues and financing long-term care over the next five decades. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit annual reports to Congress on the impact of demographic changes on long-term care services, options for addressing payment issues for nursing facility services, and financing quality long-term care over the next five decades. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit annual reports to Congress on the impact of demographic changes on long-term care services, options for addressing payment issues for nursing facility services, and financing quality nursing home care over the next five decades. The Secretary will also provide a final report to Congress within 5 years of the enactment of this Act, including the results of a study on the amendments and their impact. The final report to Congress, due within 5 years of the Act's enactment, will include results of a study on amendments' impact, recommendations for changes to Medicare payment system for extended care services, and an analysis of alternative options. Recommendations for changes to the Medicare payment system for extended care services in skilled nursing facilities to improve quality of care. Analysis of pros and cons of alternative approaches to address identified issues.
